constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Inferred quality of sleep - the latent construct we want to improve. Manifested through sleep duration, wake timing, and next-day activity patterns.

constructs.name: inferred_sleep_duration_hours
constructs.description: Hours between last daily activity and first activity next day, serving as proxy for sleep duration

constructs.name: browsing_cessation_time
constructs.description: Time of day when last browsing activity occurred, as minutes since midnight. Values >1440 indicate past-midnight activity attributed to previous day's session.

constructs.name: late_night_entry_count
constructs.description: Number of browsing entries after 10pm, indicating late-night screen engagement

constructs.name: wake_time_minutes
constructs.description: Time of first daily activity as minutes since midnight, serving as proxy for wake time

constructs.name: total_daily_activity_count
constructs.description: Total number of browsing activities in a day, indicating overall screen engagement and usage intensity

constructs.name: technical_search_count
constructs.description: Number of technical/programming searches indicating cognitive workload from knowledge work

constructs.name: evening_technical_searches
constructs.description: Technical searches after 8pm, indicating cognitively demanding work close to bedtime that may impair sleep onset

constructs.name: is_weekend
constructs.description: Whether the day is Saturday or Sunday, affecting schedule flexibility and social obligations

constructs.name: travel_period
constructs.description: Whether travel-related activity occurred, indicating disrupted routine, jet lag potential, or vacation context

constructs.name: health_search_count
constructs.description: Number of health or medical-related searches, indicating health concerns or wellness interest

constructs.name: stress_level
constructs.description: Latent daily stress level inferred from behavioral indicators like work intensity, health concerns, and browsing patterns

constructs.name: mental_arousal_before_bed
constructs.description: Latent mental activation level in evening hours, driven by stimulating content and screen exposure

constructs.name: sleep_schedule_regularity
constructs.description: Latent consistency of sleep/wake schedule over recent days, affecting circadian rhythm alignment

constructs.name: caffeine_indicator
constructs.description: Whether caffeine-related searches occurred, suggesting caffeine consumption that day

constructs.name: entertainment_evening_activity
constructs.description: Evening leisure/entertainment browsing count, can be stimulating or relaxing depending on content

constructs.name: substance_research_flag
constructs.description: Whether psychoactive substance research occurred, indicating potential substance use affecting sleep

constructs.name: very_late_night_activity
constructs.description: Whether browsing occurred after midnight, indicating severely delayed sleep or insomnia

constructs.name: search_entry_count
constructs.description: Number of search queries (vs passive visits), indicating active information-seeking behavior

edges.description: Weekends allow later bedtimes without next-day work obligations
Weekends allow sleeping in without work schedule constraints
Weekends permit more late-night screen time without consequences
Travel planning and execution increases cognitive load and stress
Travel disrupts regular sleep schedule through time zones and changed routines
High technical workload increases cognitive stress and work pressure
Days with heavy technical work tend to spill over into evening hours
Complex problem-solving in evening keeps mind active and delays wind-down
More late-night activity mechanically delays the final cessation time
Screen exposure and engagement late at night elevates arousal through blue light and content
High mental arousal impairs sleep onset latency and reduces deep sleep
Later cessation reduces wind-down time and delays sleep onset
Later cessation directly compresses the available sleep window
Elevated stress impairs sleep onset through rumination and cortisol
Stress drives escapist browsing and difficulty disengaging from screens
Poor sleep quality leads to compensatory later wake times
Sleep quality affects sleep efficiency and time spent asleep
Poor sleep increases next-day stress reactivity and impairs coping
Poor sleep reduces next-day energy and cognitive engagement capacity
High overall engagement patterns carry into nighttime hours
Irregular schedules disrupt circadian rhythm and impair sleep quality
Variable bedtimes contribute to schedule irregularity over time
Variable wake times contribute to schedule irregularity over time
Caffeine consumption can impair sleep quality through adenosine blocking
Caffeine promotes alertness enabling more late-night activity
Health concerns and symptom checking increases anxiety and stress
Evening entertainment can be stimulating (exciting content) or calming depending on type
Engaging entertainment extends browsing sessions into late hours
Sleep duration affects next-day energy for engaging with screens
Substance use (if following research) can directly impair sleep architecture
Researching psychoactive substances may indicate self-medication attempts for underlying stress
Activity past midnight severely disrupts sleep timing and circadian alignment
Very late activity directly reduces sleep opportunity window
High search activity indicates active problem-solving mode, reflecting cognitive demand
Stress drives insomnia-like patterns and delayed sleep attempts
Weekends permit staying up past midnight without work consequences
